taskDescription:
The distance from Earth to the moon is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>1.514</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mn>10</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">1.514 \times {10^{10}}</annotation></semantics></math> inches. The thickness of a dollar bill is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>4.3</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
        <mn>3</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">4.3 \times {10^{ - 3}}</annotation></semantics></math>  inches. How many dollar bills must be stacked so the pile reaches the moon?
detailedSolution:
A pile of dollar bills that reaches the moon would contain <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>3.521</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mn>12</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">3.521 \times {10^{12}}</annotation></semantics></math>  bills.
